item.title: Trump Administration Gives Three Mile Island Nuclear Project $1 Billion Loan
item.description: The Pennsylvania site, shorthand for the dangers of nuclear power after a 1979 meltdown, is set for revival under a deal to power Microsoft data centers.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:description: Constellation’s nuclear power plant, called the Crane Clean Energy Center, on Three Mile Island near Middletown, Pa. earlier this year.

item.title: Harvard Opens New Investigation Into Summers and Epstein
item.description: The university is reviewing newly released emails between convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and former Harvard President Lawrence H. Summers, among other people at the institution.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawrence H. Summers, the former president of Harvard, said he was stepping away from public commitments.

item.title: House Rejects Censuring Plaskett For Texts With Epstein In 2019
item.description: Three Republicans voted with nearly every Democrat in the House to defeat an effort to formally reprimand Delegate Stacey Plaskett, Democrat of the Virgin Islands.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro and Robert Jimison
item.media:description: Stacey Plaskett, Democrat of the Virgin Islands, during a House Committee on the Judiciary hearing at the Capitol, last year.

item.title: Trump Ramps Up Redistricting Pressure on Indiana Republicans
item.description: After the State Senate said it would not take up a new map, President Trump said he would support primary challengers against Republicans who bucked him.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:description: Gov. Mike Braun of Indiana and other Republicans have argued that redistricting in Indiana was necessary to counter gerrymandering by Democrats in other states.

item.title: Democratic Lawmakers Tell Military to Refuse Illegal Orders
item.description: Six lawmakers, who all served in the military or the intelligence community, released the message in a video. The Trump administration sharply criticized the effort.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marines and members of the National Guard were deployed to Los Angeles to assist immigration agents this summer.

item.title: Once a Pariah, Saudi Prince Resets U.S. Relations on His Own Terms
item.description: Seven years ago, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman couldn’t visit Washington. When he arrived at the White House on Tuesday, he got F-35s, the world’s fastest chips and the central role in the remaking of the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Mohammed bin Salman, the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia, leaving the White House on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Federal Judge Orders Some Texas Schools to Remove Ten Commandment Posters
item.description: The judge sided with families of students who had argued that the displays infringed on their religious freedom.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Texas law requires school districts to display the Ten Commandments in a “conspicuous location” in each classroom.

item.title: Trump Lauds M.B.S. During White House Visit and Dismisses Khashoggi’s Killing
item.description: President Trump rejected a U.S. intelligence report finding that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman had ordered the murder of a journalist.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Trump and Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince and prime minister of Saudi Arabia, in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: Republican Clay Higgins Was the Sole Vote Against Releasing the Epstein Files
item.description: The only person in Congress to vote against the bill was a right-wing congressman from Louisiana who is an ardent supporter of President Trump and has espoused conspiracy theories.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Representative Clay Higgins, Republican of Louisiana, during a Homeland Security Committee hearing at the Capitol last year.

item.title: Trump Said to Authorize C.I.A. Plans for Covert Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has signed off on possible operations inside Venezuela but has also reopened back-channel communications with the government of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The next phase of the Trump administration’s escalating pressure campaign on the government of President Nicolás Maduro could be sabotage or some sort of cyber, psychological or information operations.

item.title: Here’s Who’s Attending Trump’s Dinner for the Saudi Crown Prince: Elon Musk, Cristiano Ronaldo and more.
item.description: The guests at President Trump’s dinner for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia included prominent figures in sports and business.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: J.D. Vance, Not That One, Gets 2 Years in Prison for Threatening the Vice President
item.description: James Donald Vance Jr., of Grand Rapids, Mich., had also threatened President Trump, according to a criminal complaint.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: President Trump and Vice President JD Vance on Veterans Day.

item.title: For Trump, Epstein Is the Story That Won’t Go Away
item.description: President Trump is being held captive to a news cycle he can’t avoid or defeat when it comes to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump with Jeffrey Epstein in New York City in 1997.

item.title: Behind the Vote to Release the Epstein Files
item.description: The House approved a bill directing the Justice Department to release all files related to its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, in a near-unanimous vote. Hours later, Senator Chuck Schumer won unanimous agreement for the Senate to pass the measure as soon as it arrived in the chamber.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni, Claire Hogan and James Surdam

item.title: House Condemns García’s Election Scheme Amid Democratic Split
item.description: The measure rebuked the retiring Democratic representative Jesús García of Illinois for maneuvering to ensure his top aide would be the only one running to succeed him.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Jesús García has denied wrongdoing and said he followed his state’s rules and election law.

item.title: Kamala Harris Hits Campaign Trail in Tennessee Special Election
item.description: On Tuesday, the former vice president made her first campaign appearance for another Democrat since leaving office.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Former Vice President Kamala Harris arriving at a campaign event for State Representative Aftyn Behn on Tuesday in Nashville.

item.title: Elon Musk Puts Trump Feud Behind Him and Tiptoes Back Into Politics
item.description: Having struck an uneasy truce with the president, Elon Musk is starting to make political appearances again, and his allies are planning a DOGE reunion party.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:description: Elon Musk at Charlie Kirk’s memorial service in September. On Tuesday, he attended a formal dinner that President Trump held for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.

item.title: ‘Things Happen’: Trump Brushes Off the Murder of Khashoggi
item.description: A reporter asked Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman about the murder of the Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi. President Trump interjected.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:description: President Trump responds to a reporter’s question about the murder of the Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi on Tuesday.

item.title: How Trump Has Used ICE, the National Guard and Other Federal Forces Across the U.S.
item.description: Charlotte and Raleigh in North Carolina became the latest cities to see federal forces move in. Here’s a rundown of what’s going on in each place.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Border Patrol agents questioned Chicagoans about their immigration status on the southwest side of the city this month.

item.title: Trump Administration Announces Steps to Dismantle Education Department
item.description: Responsibilities for K-12 and college programs, among others, will be moved to other federal agencies.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Education building in Washington last week.

item.title: Federal Court Blocks Texas’ Republican-Friendly Congressional Map
item.description: The move dealt a blow to efforts by Texas Republicans and President Trump to flip Democratic seats in the state. Texas quickly filed a notice of appeal to the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and J. David Goodman
item.media:description: A voter looking in August at a proposed redistricting map that was approved by Texas lawmakers for the 2026 midterm elections.

item.title: Texas Governor Declares Muslim Civil Rights Group a ‘Terrorist Organization’
item.description: Gov. Greg Abbott said the state could now take steps to shut down the Council on American-Islamic Relations. The group said the declaration had no basis in fact or law.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Carter Johnston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas at a bill signing ceremony in Austin in September.

item.title: Investigators Zero In on Cause of Ship Outage Before Bridge Crash: A Misplaced Label
item.description: At a hearing on the crash that led to the collapse of the Key Bridge in Baltimore, investigators said a tiny sticker had caused a wire to disconnect, prompting blackouts and system failures.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:description: Six people were killed when a cargo ship hit the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore in 2024.

item.title: Trump Library Foundation Expects to Raise $50 Million This Year
item.description: President Trump is raising money far faster than his predecessors, extracting tens of millions of dollars in pledged donations from media companies he has sued.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold
item.category: Obama, Barack H, Presidential Library and Museum
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Monday in Washington. The Donald J. Trump Presidential Library Foundation expects to raise about $50 million this year.

item.title: Trump Team Calls Maduro a ‘Cartel’ Boss. That Word Doesn’t Mean What You Think.
item.description: Venezuelans coined a figure of speech for the phenomenon of generals corrupted by drug money: “Cartel de los Soles.” Then the United States started talking about it as a literal organization.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump Treasury Department officially labeled Cartel de los Soles a global terrorist entity in July.

item.title: Border Patrol Expands North Carolina Operations to More Liberal Cities
item.description: Agents were active in the Raleigh and Durham areas on Tuesday, though the scope of the immigration crackdown in the state’s Research Triangle region was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina, Emily Cataneo and Meredith Honig
item.media:description: Since Saturday, the Border Patrol had been focusing its efforts in North Carolina on Charlotte, the state’s largest city, which is home to a growing population of immigrants.

item.title: Election Officials Press Trump Administration Over Voter Data
item.description: Ten Democratic officials who oversee elections in their states sent a letter to Attorney General Pam Bondi and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem demanding answers on how private voter data was being used.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, left, and Pam Bondi, the attorney general. Under Ms. Bondi, the Justice Department has embarked on an effort to compile the largest set of national voter roll data it has ever collected.

item.title: Wife of Astronaut Pleads Guilty to Falsely Alleging Crime in Space
item.description: Summer Worden admitted lying to federal agents when she accused her spouse, the astronaut Anne McClain, of illegally accessing her bank account from space.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Anne McClain was on the International Space Station in 2019 when her estranged spouse falsely accused her of illegally accessing her bank account.

item.title: Congress Overwhelmingly Approves Releasing Epstein Files
item.description: After a near-unanimous House vote, the Senate agreed to quickly clear the bill for President Trump’s signature.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: As soon as the resolution passed, Democrats, among them Teresa Leger Fernandez of New Mexico, center, turned and applauded the House gallery where survivors of Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender, were seated.

item.title: House Democrats Press for Vote to Bar Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: The effort would invoke the War Powers Act, which expedites action on measures limiting the president’s war-making authority. It faces long odds in the G.O.P.-led House.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Gregory Meeks of New York, the top Democrat on the Foreign Affairs Committee, is leading the effort in the House.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: The president is offering the crown prince fighter jets, a nuclear agreement and other deals as part of his efforts to collect investment and push forward on Middle East peace.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Vivian Nereim
item.category: Dar Al Arkan Real Estate Development Co

item.title: What to Know About How the Times/KFF Survey of Immigrants Was Conducted
item.description: The survey provides a rare look at the lives and opinions of immigrants of varying backgrounds and legal statuses
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Under Trump, Immigrants Are More Fearful but Determined to Stay, Poll Finds
item.description: A national survey found that half of all immigrants in the United States say they feel less safe since President Trump took office. Still, many say their future remains bright.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Ruth Igielnik, Ana Ley and Ashley Cai

item.title: With Trump in Office, a Transgender Trailblazer and American Diplomat Seeks Refuge Abroad
item.description: Robyn McCutcheon, the first American diplomat to come out as transgender, helped to shape personnel and foreign policy at the State Department. The country she served doesn’t feel like home anymore.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: Ms. McCutcheon embraced her boyfriend, John Quinn, for the last time before she left the country.
